9/ David Harding ( @ hrdng) said it best: “So the real achievement of MAST is not that it allows Bitcoin users to create more advanced smart contracts than before, but that it does so without placing any new worst-case burdens on Bitcoin nodes.”
8/ It also improves functionality in that with MAST we can add more subscripts for more complex smart contracts while avoiding bumping up against byte size hard limits.

7/ MAST also improves privacy in that we minimize the scope of a contract that must be published publicly on-chain for anyone to see. As a result, a greater portion of the smart contact’s terms remain private to its participants.
6/ David Harding ( @ hrdng) visualized the benefits in the graphic below which comes from his phenomenal post here that I *highly* recommend: http://bit.ly/2AAxGyB pic.twitter.com/Cxk4ccP5Vt

5/ This improves efficiency in that we avoid burdening the network with irrelevant portions of the smart contract—this helps minimize data processing and storage requirements for network participants (e.g. full nodes).

4/ In any given smart contract it’s likely that only a portion may be relevant to a particular tx and, with MAST, we can reduce what’s published on-chain to only the portion of the contract that is relevant to the tx being broadcast.
3/ Recently, @ waxwing__ aptly described this as the best way to “cut the Gordian knot” of privacy vs. scalability.https://twitter.com/waxwing__/status/968493256572063744 …

2/ As with prior posts on Schnorr Sigs (http://bit.ly/2I1MaIM ) and Scriptless Scripts (http://bit.ly/2FbNw5S ), MAST’s efficiency, privacy, and functionality advantages are obtained primarily by minimizing on-chain data processing and storage demands
